The Buddha said:
There are four great dharmas from which one can obtain blessings and attain the Way, with the same blessings as attaining the Buddha's body.

The World-Honored One said:

You should raise the young and weak with a compassionate mind. When you see lowly birds, beasts, insects, and moths that depend on humans for survival, you should always have pity on them, provide them with food, and let them rest. Do not use knives or sticks to harm or end their lives. Have a compassionate heart, like a loving mother.
Celestial dragons, spirits, emperors, and people who practice this compassion will receive great blessings, equal to the merit of serving the Buddha's body.
This is called the first matter.

In the world, there are calamities and anomalies, floods and droughts are not in balance, the five grains are not abundant, the people are starving, they are not at ease in their homeland, and they wish to rebel and leave.

If the king, ministers, and people have abundant grain in their storehouses, they should consider impermanence and the difficulty of protecting their own lives. Do not love precious grains, but know how to love human life. They should give rise to a compassionate heart, take out grain from their storehouses, and lend it to the poor to save their lives, so that they can live at ease in their homeland.
If one is stingy and greedy, unwilling to give, one should contemplate:
When a person is first born, the soul comes empty, relying on the emotional energy of the two parents to form one's body.
In the mother's womb, after ten months it is born, and if it receives the joy of the parents, it can maintain its life.
If it is sorrowful and angry, it will be cut off immediately. If it is extremely distressed, it will end, but the soul does not perish, and it will seek another body.
Whether noble or humble, rich or poor, is all due to past actions.
Official rank, salary, country, treasures, do not be deluded by them, let them disturb one's lofty virtue. When one's life ends, the body and treasures remain in the world, not following one away.

One should always be kind-hearted, cultivate practices, and follow the Buddha's teachings to observe people and things, like an illusion, like a transformation, like a dream, like an echo, all are empty and cannot last. Observing the world is like this, this is true reality.

Worldly people are foolish and deluded, their minds harboring inversions. They deceive themselves and mislead others, as if using gold to buy brass. When the body dies and the spirit departs, they will fall into the three evil paths.
Contemplate this carefully;
Quickly make offerings, competing with your own life. To the poor, beggars, the weak, the old, and the sick, give according to what is appropriate, do not let life end.
Uphold the mind like this, the Buddhas of the ten directions, the great beings of the bodhisattva stage, the devas, nÄgas, ghosts and spirits, none will not have compassion for you.

Up to the end of life, the soul and spirit will be reborn, and will immediately receive nobility and wealth, with body and mind both at ease. Calamities will not arise, and you will fully attain the supreme vows, just like making offerings to the Buddha's body when the Buddha was present, exactly the same without difference.
This is called the second matter.

In the country, there are many thieves, fires, and disasters. Plagues spread, and diseases run rampant. All of this is done by the dragon kings and ghost kings in the ocean. Therefore, we suffer from these serious illnesses and worries.
These ghosts, spirits, and dragons are all those who, in their previous lives as humans, engaged in hunting, killing, and fishing.

Their souls fell into the ocean and became dragons, or powerful spirits born through transformation. They all know their past lives and harbor resentment from their past grudges. They create fog and mist, spew poisonous air, and rain it down on the country.

At that time, some people die from poisoning, some only get sick, and some are smeared with it. All of this is due to the unkindness and killing of life by people in the world, which leads to mutual resentment.
Those who kill with their own hands die from poisoning;
Those who rejoice in it all become more troubled and sick;
Whether they smear each other or do not smear each other is all due to those who eat meat having a shared aspect or not having a shared aspect.
The wise who listen and understand, realize that the sin of killing pursues people and does not cease, and by taking themselves as a measure for others, it is exactly the same.
If one reveres and practices in this way, the Buddha's vast path, practicing the four equal minds - kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity - the blessings will naturally return to oneself.
If a butcher's family gives meat to oneself, one should be cautious and not eat it.
Those who do not eat it, even if they are in a bad world, in times of disasters from thieves and bandits, or poisonous qi, even if they are in the midst of it, they will not be smeared by it.

If the emperor and the people are wealthy and have surplus grain, the orphaned, widowed, and childless do not have enough clothing and food, and are suffering from illness and infirmity, without means to save themselves, they should be provided with medicine, gruel, and nourishment, so that they may recover, and their lives will not be cut short.

One should clarify that this person has committed evil in past lives, does not believe in the Three Jewels, turns away from the true and towards the false, and is caused by stinginess and greed. Retribution of good and evil is clear, so one should be cautious and not do evil;
One should also have a compassionate mind and use the Buddhist scriptures to teach and admonish the ignorant, causing them to uphold the scriptures.

If one saves a person and cures their illness, shows them the right path, causes them to uphold the five precepts, and be pure and clean for the rest of their life, the merit is equal to serving the Buddha's body.
These are the three matters.
In the world, there are those of lofty virtue, purity, and few desires, who are ascetics and brahmins. They carry the scriptures in their minds, and their words are in accordance with the Dharma.
The emperor, ministers, and people should be respectful and reverent, and go to them to receive the precepts and practice.

What these lofty people speak from their mouths are all the remaining teachings of the Buddhas, causing people to abandon evil and do good. Their kindness is more than a hundred times greater than that of relatives, causing people to have a long life and not fall into the three evil paths. One should always have a compassionate mind and be respectful towards them.
It is better to have molten copper poured into one's mouth or to have one's tongue cut off with a sharp knife, but one should never slander and defame these pure people;
It is better to cut off one's own hand than to inflict pain on others;
It is better to cut open one's own abdomen and burn one's heart than to be angry with these people.

Even if fools see the Buddha's scriptures and teachings, they clearly know what to do and what to avoid, but due to their distance from the wise, they join the ignorant masses, and by lecturing on and receiving the sacred scriptures, they attain lofty virtue.

They protect and uphold their alms bowls, laboriously begging for food to sustain their mouths, stopping immediately, not hoarding leftovers;
They may live in temples, or in mountains, forests, under trees, or in charnel grounds, all knowing their past lives;
They discern true and false, compose scriptures and treatises, become bridges for the world, have compassionate minds, and pity many;
They sit and rise, making aspirations for emperors and ministers, causing the country to be peaceful and stable.

Such a great person, with virtue and instruction for the gods, dragons, and ghosts, does not pursue worldly affairs, and therefore does not fall into the loss of emotional desires, but is only praised and extolled.

If the king, ministers, and people have wisdom, they should seek them out and provide them with clothing, food, bedding, and medical treatment for illnesses, making them comfortable, allowing them to expound the scriptures and precepts, spread the teachings, sit in meditation and contemplate concentration, or attain the Way, or upon death ascend to the heavens;

The clothing and food of a defiled person in a country is not as good as wholeheartedly making offerings to a single pure and virtuous practitioner. Their merit is vast, just like making offerings to the Buddha's body during the Buddha's time, exactly the same without difference.
This is called the four things.
The emperor, ministers, and people view such people, and the gods, dragons, and ghosts all protect and assist them with joy.
